Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research:HF-Isotopes as Tracers of Highly Depleted Oceanic Mantle
Award.AbstractNarration: Volcanic activity on mid-ocean ridges constitutes one of the largest scale and most important chemical differentiation processes on earth. Magmas, created from the selective melting of Earth's mantle, bring some elements and elemental ratios to Earth's surface and leave others behind as residues in Earth's mantle. Of all the potential geochemical tracers examined to date, Hafnium (Hf) and Neodymium (Nd) appear to be the most powerful in helping us understand not only the chemical evolution of the mantle but also the ages and process of melt segregation and mid-ocean ridge volcanism. This research will use samples of abyssal peridotite from various mid-ocean ridges, emphasizing samples from the recently discovered ultra-slow spreading Gakkel Ridge in the Arctic, where mantle rocks outcrop on the seafloor. It will focus on determining the fraction of the mantle source that melts to form the vast majority of volcanic rocks erupted on the seafloor. To make this determination, trace elements and Hf and Nd isotopes will be measured, with the Hf isotopes illuminating the melting process and Nd providing age constraints. This work complements, but does not overlap with, a geochemical study of Gakkel abyssal peridotites. Broader impacts of the work include student training in state-of-the art geochemical analytical techniques and engaging high school students and their teachers in the research. It will also involve the high school participants in the laboratory and its activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are three key outcomes:

1. Hf and Nd isotopes in abyssal peridotites are not correlated. This is best explained if the Nd isotopes are more effected by re-equilibration with melts on their way to the surface that the Hf isotopic composition. However, even with re-equilibration the Nd isotopic composition of a significant number of peridotites is more radiogenic than the nearby basalts. These residual characteristics are best fit in a model where the re-equilibration with a melt after depletion is older (i.e. unrelated to the recent ascent to the seafloor).

 

2. The abyssal peridotites for which we have isotope analyses, on average, represent only part of the source that contributes to the associated MORB. The difference between basalt and peridotite in Hf isotopic composition is much more pronounced: the majority of the Hf isotopes are more radiogenic than the nearby basalts and some have extreme radiogenic compositions. On the other hand peridotite compositions that are less radiogenic in Nd or Hf occur only sporadically. Whether or not the peridotite are “pure” residuals or whether they have seen some degree of interaction with melt is semantic with respect to the differences in isotopic composition between peridotite and aggregated melts as seen on the seafloor.  The consequence is that different parts of the mantle contribute different amounts of melt to aggregated MORB. Assuming relatively homogeneous temperatures over small length scales this observation implies that the melting rates for different parts (components) of the sub ridge mantle varies. This scenario has the potential to explain the presence of garnet signatures in basalts in areas where the crust is thin or normal. When a significant part of the mantle contributes little melt, other parts have to melt more (i.e., start melting deeper) to generate the observed crustal thickness.

3. The depletion ages for the peridotites relatively young. Although Nd, Hf, and Os ages are not correlated all ages are relatively young and any evidence of ancient depletions have been eradicated. This has a consequence for the recycling time in the mantle which has to be faster that previously thought as larger scale heterogeneities requires several turnover times before they are dispersed enough that they have lost their own identity on the scale of sampling.
